thread.title: New working group could slow Denver ethics code changes
thread.title_full: New working group could slow Denver ethics code changes - The Denver Post

author: Jon Murray
title: New working group could slow Denver ethics code changes
text:
The Board of Ethics had hoped to pitch the City Council soon on proposed changes to beef up gift limits and other parts of the Denver ethics code, but its chairman has agreed to slow down to get more input through a new working group.
Past attempts to strengthen ethical requirements for Denver elected officials, appointees and thousands of employees have proved politically tricky . The working group — requested by Mayor Michael Hancock's city attorney, Scott Martinez — could result in wider support for potential changes before they are taken to the council.
But that extra step also could slow the process. On Wednesday, chairman Brian Spano told fellow board members that he was determined to avoid a stall-out and was optimistic, given that Martinez had agreed to co-chair the working group with him.
The working group will include representatives from the city, the public and the mayor's office, Spano said. He also wants to include the League of Women Voters of Denver, Colorado Common Cause and another ethics board member.
"I'm not cynical, and I'm actually encouraged by that because the city attorney is prepared to put his name and associate his name with potential changes to the code," Spano said.
Still, Spano, a Denver attorney, said he was skeptical at first.
Advertisement "My immediate reaction to that was (that) I'm fine having those who have an interest in expressing their views about possible changes to the code to do so," he said, "but I did not want to see this drag out. ... So I've received assurances that won't happen."
Spano said he hoped to get the working group formed and have an initial meeting in the next 30 days, with the panel meeting three or four times before recommending changes.
It will use as a baseline the most recent list cobbled together over the last year during discussions by the board, Spano said.
Among the biggest potential changes: Setting a maximum annual value of $250 per donor or business for gifts of meals and event tickets to an official or employee in position to take action that benefits the donor; expanding the definition in the conflict-of-interest rules of family members who can't benefit from contracts or official action; adding restrictions on soliciting donations for the city or outside charities or nonprofits; and closing a loophole that allows for-profit organizations to funnel potentially barred gifts through nonprofit groups.
The last item has gained notice from the administration. Hancock came under fire last year for the financing of his trip to the Super Bowl and was dinged by the ethics board , though it found no wrongdoing.
The ethics board is still considering other ideas, including expanding rules governing outside employment and side jobs by city employees.
